title: Remarkable tale of survival of cockatoo who was shot five times
text:
A cockatoo has remarkably survived being shot five times.

The sulphur-crested cockatoo, named Mr Cocky, was brought into the Avian Reptile and Exotic Pet Hospital in Camden, south of Sydney, after he was found injured in a backyard in September.

A vet posted the images of an x-ray of the bird to Facebook, commenting on how disgusted they were at the bird's treatment.

A cockatoo's injuries told a remarkable story of survival after a vet found the bird had been shot five time yet had not been killed (pictured)

'After a physical examination it was noticeably evident that his left wing had a reduced range of motion,' the post read.

'Much to the shock of the hospital, radiographs revealed a total of 5 bullets from two different rifles! One of the lead bullets was merely millimetres away from his left eye. To say he is one lucky bird is an understatement.'

Vet Lorenzo Crosta told ABC News he couldn't believe what he found after giving the bird an x-ray.

Mr Cocky had two pellets embedded in his chest, with the others found above his left eye and in his shoulder.

'I mean, he's like winning the national lottery, this one, he's definitely very lucky being alive,' Dr Crosta told the publication.

Dr Crosta was able to remove all but the pellet in the bird's shoulder which he said at the moment isn't limiting the bird too much.

It is expected Mr Cocky will be on the recovery trail for a number of months before he will be freed back into the wild.

'For now, Mr Cocky is enjoying his daily physiotherapy to increase his range of motion so that he may one day be released and given a second chance at life,' the post read.

Cockatoos are a protected species in New South Wales under the Biodiversity Conservation Act of 2016.

The maximum penalty for shooting a cockatoo is a fine up to $22,000 and five years in jail.

If you see someone partaking in such acts, please call the RSPCA on 1300 CRUELTY.
